course.title: Basics of Software for Vibe Coding

content.body:
**Vibe coding** is building software by describing what you want in natural language instead of writing code yourself. You tell an AI app builder (like Lovable) how your app should look, feel, and behave, and it turns your words into working features.

Think of it as having a conversation with a developer who builds exactly what you describe. The better you can explain what you want, the better the results!

steps.title: How apps are built

content.body:
Picture a bakery: there's the front counter where customers order, a kitchen where the baking happens, and a storage room for ingredients.

Apps work the same way! Each part has a specific job. Once you know what they're called, you can tell your AI app builder exactly where you want changes made. No more vague requests that lead to confusing results.

steps.subtitle: Think of it like a bakery

content.body:
Every app has two main parts: the **frontend** (what users see and interact with) and the **backend** (the behind-the-scenes brain that makes everything work).

When you're prompting an AI app builder (like Lovable), knowing which part you're talking about helps the AI understand exactly what to build or fix. It's like giving directions: "turn left at the bakery" works much better than "go that way."

The **frontend** is everything your users interact with: buttons, forms, images, animations. It runs right on their phone or laptop (that's why it's also called the **client**).

When you prompt something like *"make the signup button bigger and pink,"* you're asking for a frontend change. Think of it as the friendly cashier handing over your cinnamon roll, it's what the customer actually sees and touches.

The **backend** handles things that need to happen somewhere else: saving user data, sending emails, processing payments. These programs run on powerful computers called **servers**.

When you prompt *"send a welcome email when someone signs up,"* that's a backend task. It's like the baker working behind the scenes, customers never see them, but they make everything delicious happen.

Servers live in huge buildings called data centres, that are ran by companies specialised in them.

Instead of buying our own computers, we rent space on theirs. This is **cloud computing** (or just "the cloud").

The beautiful thing about tools like Lovable? They handle all this server stuff for you automatically. You just describe what you want, and the infrastructure appears like magic. One less thing to worry about!

For bigger apps, whole teams manage the **infrastructure**: all those servers, networks, and services working together.

You won't need to worry about this when starting out, but it's handy to know the word when you hear it. If someone mentions "infrastructure," they're talking about all the technical plumbing that keeps apps running smoothly.

The **database** is where your app remembers things: user profiles, orders, blog posts, favourite recipes, you name it. It's a program on the server that stores and organises information so your backend can find it whenever it's needed.

When you prompt *"let users save their favourite recipes,"* you're asking for database storage. Most AI app builders use Supabase to handle this for you, so you don't need to set anything up yourself.

content.question: Which part of an app runs on the user's device?
content.explanation:
The frontend runs on your user's device and shows them the interface. The backend runs on servers and handles logic. The database stores information. Infrastructure keeps it all running.

You don't need to memorise these perfectly, just recognising them will help you write clearer prompts and understand what your AI app builder is doing!

options: The frontend displaying data from the backend
content.question: Which part of an app would handle showing a user their saved notes?
content.explanation:
It's teamwork! The backend fetches the notes from the database, then sends them to the frontend, which displays them beautifully.

When you prompt for features like this, the AI app builder coordinates all three parts automatically.

options: The app won't load images or animations.
The app looks fine but can't load or save data.
The database will automatically repair itself.
content.question: If the backend of an app stops working, what might users experience?
content.explanation:
When the backend goes down, your app still shows up (that's the frontend working!), but nothing that needs server communication works: no logging in, no saving, no loading data.

This is useful to know when troubleshooting! If buttons appear but nothing happens when you click them, it's often a backend issue.

content.description: What's one thing from this section that you'll take away? How might it change the way you describe what you want to build?
content.subDescription: Writing this down helps it stick, and you can remember it better next time you're building!

content.subDescription: It's powerful to know the difference between frontend and backend. It means you can point the AI app builder to exactly the right place. Try noticing which part you're talking about in your next prompt, it makes a real difference!

challenges.title: Building Blocks of an Application
challenges.description: Get familiar with the core parts of an app so you can brief an AI builder clearly.

steps.title: Design words that tools understand

content.body:
Have you ever tried to describe something visual and struggled to find the right words? "Make it look more... you know... modern?" doesn't give the AI app builder much to work with!

In this challenge, you'll learn terms like **wireframes, components, design systems, colours, and fonts**, the vocabulary that turns vague vibes into clear instructions. The more precise you are, the closer the AI app builder gets on the first try.

steps.subtitle: From vague vibes to clear instructions

content.body:
A **wireframe** is a quick sketch showing where things go on a screen, no colours or polish, just boxes and labels. Think of it as a blueprint before the pretty stuff.

Before you start prompting, try sketching your screen on paper or a whiteboard. It clarifies your thinking and gives you something concrete to describe. Even professional designers do this!

Grab a piece of paper and sketch the main screen of your app idea. What's at the top? What's the main action you want users to take?

steps.title: Meet the components

content.body:
**Components** are the building blocks of any screen: buttons, text fields, cards, pop-ups, navigation bars. When you name these specifically in your prompts, the AI app builder knows exactly what to create.

Instead of *"add a way to submit,"* try *"add a Submit button below the form."* See the difference? Let's look at the most common components you'll use.

steps.subtitle: The building blocks you'll use most

content.body:
**Buttons** trigger actions. You can be specific: *"primary button"* (the main action, usually colourful), *"secondary button"* (less prominent, often with just an outline), or *"tertiary button"* (could be just text without a fill, used for less critical actions).

Try prompting: *"Add a primary Save button in the bottom right corner."*

**Input fields** let users type information. A single line is an *input field*; multiple lines is a *textarea*.

You can get specific: *"Add an email input field with placeholder text 'Enter your email'."* The more detail you give, the less back-and-forth you'll need!

**Cards** group related information together, like a recipe preview or a product listing. They usually have an image, title, short description, and sometimes a button.

Try prompting: *"Show each blog post as a card with the title, date, and a Read More button."*

**Navigation bars** help users move around your app. A *nav bar* usually sits at the top with links; a *nav drawer* slides in from the side (common on mobile).

Try prompting: *"Add a top nav bar with links to Home, About, and Contact."*

**Modals** are pop-up windows that appear over everything else, usually for confirmations, alerts, or quick forms. They demand attention!

Try prompting: *"When the user clicks Delete, show a confirmation modal asking 'Are you sure?'"*

**Dropdowns** reveal a list of options when clicked. Great when you have several choices but don't want to clutter the screen.

Try prompting: *"Add a dropdown to select the category: Work, Personal, or Ideas."*

**Icons** are small symbols that communicate meaning at a glance: a trash can for delete, a magnifying glass for search, a heart for favourite.

Try prompting: *"Add a heart icon button to let users favourite items."*

There are dozens more components out there! Browse [component.gallery](https://component.gallery/components/) to discover them.

Next time you're stuck describing something, check if there's a standard component name for it, the AI app builder will understand it instantly. It's like learning that the thing you've been calling "that spinny loading circle" is actually called a "spinner."

A **design system** is a ready-made kit of components that all look good together. No more mismatched buttons!

Most AI app builders use [shadcn/ui](https://ui.shadcn.com/) by default ‚Äì beautiful, modern components right out of the box. Browse [their components page](https://ui.shadcn.com/docs/components) to see what's available. You can reference these directly: *"Use a shadcn accordion for the FAQ section."*

steps.title: Colours

content.body:
Colours are often written as **hex codes** like `#fdb226` (a warm yellow). But don't worry, AI app builders understands plain language too! *"Make the header dark blue"* works perfectly.

Want a specific shade? Google "colour picker" to find the exact hex code. But honestly, descriptive words work great for most prompts.

steps.subtitle: Hex codes or simple words, both work

content.body:
Need help picking colours that work well together? Try [coolors.co](https://coolors.co/) to generate palettes.

Start simple: 3-5 colours are plenty. A primary colour for buttons and accents, a neutral for backgrounds, and maybe one or two more. You can always refine later, don't let colour choices slow you down!

Fonts shape how your app feels. **Serif** fonts (like Times New Roman) have little feet on the letters, they feel classic and trustworthy. **Sans-serif** fonts (like Arial) are clean and modern.

Most apps use sans-serif for that fresh, approachable look. But there's no wrong answer, it depends on the vibe you're going for!

**Monospace** fonts (like Courier New) give each letter equal space, they look techy and are often used for code.

Try prompting: *"Use a monospace font for the code snippets section."*

steps.title: Finding and pairing fonts

content.body:
Browse [fonts.google.com](https://fonts.google.com/) for free fonts that the AI app builder can use. For pairing ideas, check [fontpair.co](https://fontpair.co/).

Keep it simple: one font for headings, one for body text. Try prompting: *"Use Inter for body text and Playfair Display for headings."*

steps.subtitle: One for headings, one for body

content.explanation:
Modals pop up over everything else to grab attention, perfect for confirmations, warnings, or quick forms.

In the AI app builder, try: *"Show a modal when the user clicks Delete."*

content.explanation:
Design systems give you pre-built components that already look good together. Most AI app builders use shadcn/ui, so you get beautiful, consistent design right out of the box!

Most apps go sans-serif for that fresh, friendly feel, but serif can be lovely for headings or brands going for a classic look!

content.explanation:
When you say "modal" instead of "pop-up thing," the AI app builder knows exactly what to build. Precision in, precision out!

The clearer your vocabulary, the fewer revision rounds you'll need.

content.explanation: Cards are perfect for grouping related info: a product preview, a blog post summary, a recipe. They're like little containers with a nice border that says "these things belong together."

content.explanation:
Hex codes are precise colour values used in digital design. But remember, you can also just say "warm yellow" and the AI app builder will understand!

Use hex codes when you need an exact shade; use words when close enough is fine.

steps.title: Frontend essentials

content.body:
The **frontend** is everything your users see and interact with. Under the hood, three languages work together: **HTML** (structure), **CSS** (style), and **JavaScript** (behaviour).

You don't need to write these, every AI app builder handles that! But understanding them helps you troubleshoot when things look off and give better feedback. It's like knowing what's under the bonnet of your car, even if you're not a mechanic.

steps.subtitle: The three languages that power every screen

content.body:
**HTML** (HyperText Markup Language) is the skeleton of every webpage. It defines what's on the page: headings, paragraphs, images, buttons.

When an AI app builder generates code, it's creating HTML for the structure. Think of HTML as the bones, everything else builds on top of it.

HTML is made of **elements** (also called tags) that represent different content types. Think of them as labelled boxes that stack and nest inside each other.

A page might have a big box for the header, which contains smaller boxes for the logo and navigation. It's boxes all the way down!

steps.title: How HTML elements work

content.body:
An HTML element has three parts: a **start tag**, **content**, and an **end tag**. For example: `

This is a paragraph.

`. The `

` opens it, the text is the content, and `

` closes it. You don't need to memorise this! Just know that when you see angle brackets `< >` in your app's code, that's HTML doing its job.

Here are the ones you'll see most often: - **Headings**: `

steps.subtitle: The ones you'll see most often

content.body:
Using the right element matters beyond looks. **Semantic HTML** helps screen readers assist users with visual impairments, and helps search engines understand your content (that's SEO!).

You can prompt the AI app builder to *"use semantic HTML"* or *"make sure the page is accessible."* It knows what to do, you just need to ask!

In design, components are things like buttons and cards. In code, the concept is the same but broader; a component can be anything from a single button to an entire page section.

The magic: **once a component exists, you can reuse it everywhere.** When you prompt *"use the same card style as the homepage,"* you're asking the AI app builder to reuse a component. This keeps your app consistent and saves you from repeating yourself in every prompt!

content.explanation:
HTML defines the structure: what's on the page and how it's organised. CSS makes it pretty, JavaScript makes it interactive.

They're a team! Knowing which does what helps you give better feedback when something isn't right.

When spacing looks off, you can prompt: *"Add more padding inside the card"* or *"Increase margin between the cards."* Now you know the right words!

When something isn't responding to clicks, it's usually a JavaScript issue. Good to know when troubleshooting!

challenges.title: Frontend for Vibe Coders
challenges.description: Learn the terms that make frontends appear the way you intend.

steps.title: Backend in clear English

content.body:
The **backend** is where the behind-the-scenes work happens: saving data, sending emails, connecting to other services. It's the engine room of your app!

In this challenge, you'll learn about **APIs**, **API keys**, **authentication**, and **backend functions**, the concepts that help you prompt for features that go beyond what users see. This is where your app becomes truly powerful.

steps.subtitle: The engine room of your app

steps.title: Your backend toolkit

content.body:
Most AI app builders use **Supabase** for your app as the backend. Think of Supabase as a toolkit that comes with user authentication, database storage, and more, all ready to use.

You don't need to set up servers yourself. The AI app builder and Supabase handle the heavy lifting while you focus on what your app should actually do. It's like having a whole tech team in your pocket!

steps.subtitle: Most AI app builders use Supabase

steps.title: Backend functions

content.body:
**Backend functions** are little workers that perform specific jobs: validate an email address, save data to the database, send a notification.

When you prompt something like *"send a confirmation email when someone signs up,"* the AI app builder creates a backend function to handle it. Think of them as instructions the server follows when triggered by user actions.

steps.subtitle: Little workers that do specific jobs

content.body:
Why build everything from scratch when someone else has already solved the problem? **Third-party services** handle things like sending emails (Resend, SendGrid), processing payments (Stripe), or posting to social media (Hootsuit, Buffer).

Most offer free tiers for small projects, perfect for getting started! When you need one, you can prompt: *"Integrate Stripe for payments"* and the AI app builder will guide you through connecting it.

steps.title: APIs

content.body:
An **API** (Application Programming Interface) is how apps talk to each other over the internet. When your app sends an email through Resend, it's using Resend's API. When it processes a payment through Stripe, it's using Stripe's API.

You don't need to understand the technical details, just know that APIs are the bridges connecting your app to other services. They're what make integrations possible!

steps.subtitle: How apps talk to each other

content.body:
To use a third-party service, you'll need to create an account on their website. Don't be intimidated if their dashboards look technical, they're designed for developers, but you can absolutely navigate them!

If you get stuck, search YouTube for "how to set up [service name] with Lovable" or simply ask your AI builder for step-by-step guidance. You just have to start and you'll figure it out!

An **API key** is like a password that identifies your app to a service. It's a string of characters you'll copy from the service's dashboard and paste into your AI app builder (it asks for it in a special modal and saves it to a section called "Secrets").

An API key looks like this:

`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`

‚ö†Ô∏è **Important:** Never paste API keys into your regular prompts, they could become visible in your code. AI app builders ask for it specifically in a special place on their interface; always use that!

steps.title: Authentication vs authorisation

content.body:
**Authentication** answers: "Who are you?" (signing up, logging in).

**Authorisation** answers: "What are you allowed to do?" (can this user edit? can they see admin pages?).

Supabase handles authentication beautifully. You can prompt: *"Add email signup and login"* or *"Let users sign in with Google."* For authorisation, try: *"Only let admins access the dashboard."*

steps.subtitle: Who you are vs what you can do

options: Authentication verifies identity; authorisation verifies permissions.
Authorisation verifies identity; authentication verifies permissions.

challenges.title: Backend for Vibe Coders
challenges.description: Discover how to specify behaviours, permissions, and integrations cleanly.

content.body:
Databases are where your app remembers things: users, orders, posts, settings, favourites ‚Äì everything that needs to persist between sessions.

Most apps use **relational databases**, which organise data like spreadsheets but with more structure and power. Let's demystify how they work so you can prompt with confidence!

Data lives in **tables**, which are like spreadsheets. Each table has **columns** (the headers: name, email, created_at) and **rows** (individual records: one row per user).

Every column has a **data type**: text, numbers, dates, or true/false values (called booleans). When you prompt *"users should have a name and email,"* the AI app builder creates a users table with those columns. Magic!

steps.title: Relationships

content.body:
Tables can connect to each other through **relationships**. Each row has a unique **primary key** (usually called `id`). Other tables can reference this ID using a **foreign key**.

For example: an `orders` table might have a `user_id` column that links to the `users` table. This lets you find all orders for a specific user!

When you prompt *"each user can have many projects,"* the AI app builder sets this up automatically.

steps.subtitle: How tables connect to each other

content.body:
**SQL** (Structured Query Language) is how you talk to databases. Commands like `SELECT` (get data), `INSERT` (add data), `UPDATE` (change data), and `DELETE` (remove data).

You won't write SQL yourself, but you'll see it sometimes when the AI app builder shows you what it's about to do. Recognising these words helps you understand what's happening, and when to be careful!

Here's the important truth: **deleted data is usually gone forever from the database**. There's no recycle bin. That's why the AI app builder often shows you the SQL code before running it, so you can approve changes first.

**If you can't read the SQL:** Just ask! Prompt *"Explain what this SQL will do in plain English"* before clicking confirm. A few seconds of checking can save hours of heartache.

**Backups** are copies of your database from a specific point in time. If something goes wrong, you can restore from a backup. Supabase offers automatic backups on paid plans.

Even on free plans, consider exporting important data regularly. For a side project, even a simple spreadsheet export can save you from disaster! Better safe than sorry.

Databases often store sensitive info, so access control is important. You can set rules for who can read, create, update, or delete data.

When building with an AI app builder, you'll often see **RLS** mentioned, this stands for **Row Level Security**. It's a Supabase feature that controls which rows each user can access.

For example, RLS can ensure users only see their own orders, not everyone else's. When the AI app builder asks you to "enable RLS" or shows RLS warnings, it's helping you protect your users' data.

Good news: AI app builders include security checks that scan your code before publishing. If you see warnings, don't panic, developers deal with these constantly! Just ask the AI to help fix them. You can also prompt: *"Make sure users can only see their own data"* or *"Set up RLS so users can only access their own records."*

content.question: Which of the following are basic parts of a relational database table?
content.explanation:
Tables contain rows (individual records) and columns (fields like name, email).

Think of it like a spreadsheet with strict structure! The table is the whole sheet, columns are the headers, rows are the entries.

content.question: What is a primary key?
content.explanation:
Every row has a unique primary key (usually `id`) so it can be found and referenced by other tables.

It's like a unique ID number for each record, no two rows can have the same one!

options: To link one table's primary key to another table
To define the layout of frontend components
content.question: What is the purpose of a foreign key?
content.explanation:
Foreign keys create relationships between tables. An order's `user_id` foreign key connects to the user's primary key `id`, that's how you know who placed which order!

It's the glue that connects your data together.

options: SQL is used to read, write, update, and delete data
SQL only works on the frontend
SQL is a visual design tool
content.question: What is SQL used for?
content.explanation:
SQL is the language for database operations. SELECT gets data, INSERT adds it, UPDATE changes it, DELETE removes it.

The AI app builder writes the SQL; you just need to recognise what's happening and when to double-check!

content.question: Why does this micro-course emphasise reviewing SQL before running it?
content.explanation:
Database changes can be permanent! There's no undo button for deleted data.

Always ask your AI app builder to explain SQL in plain English if you're unsure. A few seconds of checking can save hours of rebuilding!

content.nextModule: **Your next step:** Take one of your ideas and start building it in Lovable. Keep the scope tiny‚Äîone screen, one feature. Ship it, share it with someone real, and learn from their feedback. That's how real products are born. You've got this!

‚úì **You speak design language:** Wireframes, components, colours, fonts. You can describe exactly what you're picturing, no more "make it nicer."

‚úì **You know what's under the hood:** HTML, CSS, JavaScript. You can give meaningful feedback to your AI app builder and ask better questions.

‚úì **You can prompt for backend features:** APIs, authentication, backend functions. You've graduated from pretty interfaces to powerful, functional products.

‚úì **You understand data:** Tables, relationships, SQL. You can think about how your app remembers things and ask the right questions.

‚úì **You know the danger zones:** Irreversible database changes, exposed API keys. You can protect yourself from common mistakes that trip up beginners.

‚úì **You share a vocabulary with developers:** Collaboration just got so much easier. You're no longer on the outside looking in.

Tools will change, but these foundations won't. The more you practise describing what you want in this language, the more powerful your vibe coding becomes.
